awd_titl_txt: P2C2: Paleo-synoptic Changes as Recorded in the Mineral Dust in the Guliya Ice Cap, Northwestern Tibetan Plateau
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to develop an aeolian dust record for the Northern hemisphere derived from an ice core (16-125 thousand years) from the Guliya ice cap in Northwest Tibet. Specifically, the researchers will characterize the radiogenic, geochemical and morphological properties of mineral particles preserved in the ice core. These data will be compared with climate model simulations under different climate scenarios to understand the paleo-dust record sensitivity to climate variability on orbital scales and during abrupt climate events. The proposed research goals are to 1) document the variability of the nature of the aeolian dust throughout late Pleistocene, and 2) characterize the mechanisms through which the dust emission sources, and transport are linked to westerlies and the Indian Summer Monsoon systems (ISM). This project will provide new knowledge on the regional lithosphere-atmosphere-cryosphere interactions over the late Pleistocene and the Holocene in Northwest Tibet.
The potential Broader Impacts include the development of a new aeolian dust record from the Tibetan Plateau that will fill a geographic data gap in mid-latitude dust source variability and strengthen ice core geochemistry and paleoclimatology research disciplines. Other Broader impacts comprise several outreach activities including:  1) a video segment of ~5 minutes to highlight the inception of the research question, deployment of laboratory techniques, and methods; 2) A classroom lesson for use in high school and undergraduate geosciences classrooms; 3) a presentation  to discriminate the science and findings of this project to the broader community through the Columbus Science Pub outreach program.

In addition, the project will support the training of one graduate student and an early career female scientist (Post-doctoral researcher) in ice core paleoclimatology, mineralogy and modeling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major scientific goals of the project were to: 1) provide the most comprehensive ice core paleo aeolian dust dataset of the Northern Hemisphere by characterizing the radiogenic, geochemical, mineralogical, and morphological properties of mineral particles preserved in a >16kyr and a >125kyr ice core from the Guliya ice cap in Northwest Tibet; and 2) perform climate model simulations under different climate scenarios to understand the Asian dust cycle sensitivity to climate changes on orbital scales and during abrupt climatic events. The research plan of the project was based on three main analytical approaches: mineralogical, geochemical, and paleoclimate modeling.

Samples selected for the mineralogical and geochemical analyzes consisted of 72 dust filters from the Guliya Summit (GS) and Guliya Plateau (GP) cores and, for comparison, 21 soil samples collected across Tibet, (Potential Source Area (PSA) samples), including red clays from the Chinese Loess Plateau. The full set of 21 PSA samples has been prepared and analyzed by X-ray Diffraction and by Scanning Electron Microscopy for mineralogical composition and by ICP-MS for trace and Rare Earth Elements concentration, as well as for strontium/neodymium isotopic composition by TIMS (Ohio State University). The Sr-Nd isotopic compositions of the Guliya cores filters have been measured by MC-ICPMS (University of South Carolina) to achieve the highest accuracy on extremely small Nd samples. The Sr-Nd isotope signatures have been characterized only for the aeolian size fraction of the dust (<5 µm diameter). Our study shows that the Sr-Nd isotopic composition of aeolian deposits is spatially heterogeneous across Tibet, with more radiogenic 87Sr/86Sr in Northeastern Tibet, and more radiogenic 143Nd/144Nd in Western Tibet. The ice core derived aeolian dust records from the Guliya Summit and Plateau reveal that these two sites are influenced by different dust sources. A major proportion of the dust deposited at the Summit comes from the sandy and calcite-rich Taklimakan desert, northwest of the glacier. However, contrary to the GS dust, the composition of the Holocene GP dust points to a mix of West Taklimakan loess and West Kunlun moraine material. The complete Late Pleistocene 87Sr/86Sr and 143Nd/144Nd time series of the GP core shows a statistically significant temporal variability as well. However, variations are not correlated to paleo-temperature (δ18O of the ice). This indicates that the variation of dust sources between warm and cold climate phases is not binary. In other words, there are no two distinct sources of dust to Guliya. The GP dust time series represent a mix of multiple sources which changes through time. The gray clay collected within the bottom 10 m of the GP core has unusually radiogenic Sr and Nd values which do not match any of the known Central Asian deserts. The most radiogenic values indicate that the source material (rock) of the Guliya grey clays is very old.

We conducted a pre-industrial moisture source tracking modeling experiment by 16O tagging with iTRACE. We found that summer convection and moisture recycling over the Tibet provides a large amount of moisture to most of the region, and the westerlies contribute to ~20% moisture to the NW Tibet precipitation. In winter all moisture sources (westerlies, Indian Ocean, recycling above Tibet) contribute equally to the precipitation in NW Tibet.

The project provided training to the PI (female postdoc) in specific geochemistry procedures (i.e., the Sr-Nd column chemistry preparation and analyses by TIMS and ICPMS), and mineralogical analyses by SEM-EDS and XRD. These acquired skills complement her analytical expertise in the field of cryo-geochemistry.

A classroom lesson, using data from the project, has been developed and taught twelve times to high school, undergraduate, and graduate students during the project period. This lesson will still be taught by the PI, and will be published and made available to educators on the NAGT website. A project webpage has been created and will be kept updated with the project’s research and outreach products. An introductory segment of a 5-min project video has been completed by an OSU undergraduate student and was used independently in the classroom lesson. Most of the project’s laboratory procedures and experiments have been filmed and the video have been edited by a high school intern. The PI served as a supervisor to a junior high school student from underserved communities adjacent to the OSU campus. She trained the student at elementary clean laboratory practice and entrusted him with classification of the project’s data. The student intern also helped editing mini film clips that are included in the final project’s video and the classroom lesson. The PI participated in several international conferences and outreach events during which she highlighted her research work on the Guliya ice core dust source tracking.

This project provides the first mid-latitude Late Pleistocene record of dust composition. It will serve as a fundamental reference for future palaeoclimatological and ice core microbiological research.
